results.title: Vidocq a Bicetre = Vidocq in Bicetre Prison
results.brief_description:
Vidocq is doing an other stint in prison, just time enough to organise his next escape via the asylum section. While Annette waits anxiously with a carriage outside the prison, Vidocq and friend are held captive by the lunatics. Convinced the two intruders are demons, the asylum patients decide to put the men on trial.

Credits: Producer, Etienne Laroche ; director, Claude Loursais ; writer, Georges Neveux ; photography, Maurice Damien ; music, Serge Gainsbourg.
Cast: Bernard Noel, Alain Mottet, Genevieve Fontanel, Helene Dieudonne, Serge Gainsbourg.

results.title: Videotape editing
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “BBC Television training film”
Describes techniques of editing in videotape recording for television. Commencing with part of a live studio program being recorded on tape and passing on to a detailed description of how video tape recording machines work.

results.title: Videosphere 'Space Helmet' CRT Television Set
results.brief_description:
Videosphere was a JVC CRT television that was shaped in the form of a space helmet. It was first introduced in 1970 and was sold up until the early-1980s. It was popular for its modern design; the alarm clock base was an option however most units have a plain base.

Videospheres were produced in large quantities in white, red, black and orange in the seventies with a grey colored model also released in the 1980s. The design of the videosphere is said to have been inspired by the film 2001: A Space Odyssey,[1] though the videosphere’s shape in itself remains as one of the most iconic examples of the early 1970s design ethos.

The sci-fi look of the TV saw a red model appear as a background prop in the 1999 film The Matrix, though they have appeared in sci-fi films since the early 70s. Soylent Green had a red model on screen as a prop.The 1972 film Conquest of the Planet of the Apes, a black videosphere was shown with a color capable tube and a slot that allowed a cassette tape capable of playing video. Humorously, the color image on the videosphere goes from being rectangular in one scene to round in another scene.

JVC Videosphere / Made in Japan / (Yokohama) / Serial # 10600147
240 V / 50Hz / 12V / 11W (Australian AC power plug). Has plastic casing, control dials positioned at the back of object with an aerial and chain to hang unit.

results.title: Videos on Australian Writers: archival writers series II
results.brief_description: The second series of Archival Film Programs on Australian writers contains minimally-edited interviews with writers at home and at ease. We listen to their anecdotes, personal philosophies and are given a rare insight into their influences and motivations. These archival interviews are unique slices of social history and provide a picture of early Australia.

results.title: Videogames supercut
results.brief_description: Today’s videogames focus as much on emotion as they do action. Through evolving technical expertise and the power of narrative, character and story are now as vital to a memorable gaming experience as ammo clips and power-ups.

constellations_primary.name: Action, emotion and videogames
constellations_primary.description: More and more, videogames are beginning to favour emotion as much as action, just like their film and TV cousins.

results.description: Today’s videogames focus as much on emotion as they do action. Through evolving technical expertise and the power of narrative, character and story are now as vital to a memorable gaming experience as ammo clips and power-ups. This video interweaves scenes from AAA, indie games and everything in-between to explore the emotional impact of games, as well as the white-knuckle tension of battle, how time can be manipulated for dramatic effect and how artistic expressions like movement and dance are bringing a human element to gaming.
description_for_label: Today’s videogames focus as much on emotion as they do action. Through evolving technical expertise and the power of narrative, character and story are now as vital to a memorable gaming experience as ammo clips and power-ups. This video interweaves scenes from AAA, indie games and everything in-between to explore the emotional impact of games, as well as the white-knuckle tension of battle, how time can be manipulated for dramatic effect and how artistic expressions like movement and dance are bringing a human element to gaming.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Games Lab

results.title: Videogames and Us
results.brief_description: Since videogames were first invented in laboratories, our relationship to play has evolved. From arcades and the first home consoles to today’s blockbuster releases, mobile games and experimental indies, how we interpret and experience vieogames has changed alongside us.

constellations_primary.name: Arcades and AI
constellations_primary.description: Using the godfather of computing, Alan Turing, as a starting point, this Constellation traces the evolution of AI representation on-screen and the way female androids, robots and holograms have been hyper sexualised.

results.description: Play is an essential part of who we are as individuals and as a collective. Since videogames were first invented by scientists in laboratories, our relationship to play has come a long way. From arcades and the first home consoles to today’s blockbuster releases, mobile games and experimental indies, videogames have evolved dramatically and so have we. How we interpret and experience videogames, and the communities and cultures spawned from them, reveals much about how society has shifted in the past five decades.
description_for_label: Play is an essential part of who we are as individuals and as a collective. results.title: Videodrome
results.creator_credit: Filmplan International, Claude Heroux, David Cronenberg and Guardian Trust Company
results.brief_description: Sci-fi horror filmmaker David Cronenberg’s diabolical invader is a television show that seduces and controls its viewers. Featuring Deborah Harry as a kinky hostess, James Woods as a cable programmer looking for the ultimate in viewing thrills, this is a pulsating science fiction nightmare about a world where video can insidiously control and alter human life.
